articles.headline: U.S. Indicts Two in Switzerland on Tax Charges
articles.snippet: The move opens a new front in Washington’s crackdown on Switzerland’s tradition of bank secrecy.
articles.abstract: The move opens a new front in Washington’s crackdown on Switzerland’s tradition of bank secrecy.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Justice Department indicted a Swiss private banking executive and a Swiss lawyer on Thursday, accusing them of selling tax evasion services to wealthy clients. The move opens a new front in Washington’s challenge to Switzerland’s tradition of bank secrecy.

articles.headline: Most Failing Banks Are Doing It the Old-School Way
articles.snippet: Seventy-seven banks have had to be shut so far this year, but not because they dabbled in exotic financial products.
articles.abstract: Seventy-seven banks have had to be shut so far this year, but not because they dabbled in exotic financial products.
articles.lead_paragraph: Banks are now losing money and going broke the old-fashioned way: They made loans that will never be repaid.

articles.headline: A-List Stars Flailing at the Box Office
articles.snippet: Studios aren’t giving up on stars but they are trying to pay them less or looking for cheaper alternatives.
articles.abstract: Studios aren’t giving up on stars but they are trying to pay them less or looking for cheaper alternatives.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES  The spring and summer box office has murdered megawatt stars like Denzel Washington, Julia Roberts, Eddie Murphy, John Travolta, Russell Crowe, Tom Hanks, Adam Sandler and Will Ferrell.

articles.headline: Decaying Soviet Infrastructure Shows Its Era
articles.snippet: The failure of the Sayano-Shushenskaya dam in Siberia and the workers killed in that accident raise a larger question: Are there more tragic breakdowns ahead?
articles.abstract: The failure of the Sayano-Shushenskaya dam in Siberia and the workers killed in that accident raise a larger question: Are there more tragic breakdowns ahead?
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW  A devastating breach in Russia’s largest hydroelectric dam reminded Russians and foreign investors alike this week of the dangers posed by this country’s largely Soviet-era infrastructure.

articles.headline: Natural Gas Prices Plummet to a Seven-Year Low
articles.snippet: The sharp price decline of natural gas was attributed to declining demand and a big expansion of domestic production.
articles.abstract: The sharp price decline of natural gas was attributed to declining demand and a big expansion of domestic production.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON  Natural gas prices plunged on Thursday to levels last reached in 2002 after an Energy Department report showed that the amount of gas in storage had hit a record high for this time of year.

articles.headline: Rise of the Superrich Hits a Sobering Wall
articles.snippet: Over the last two years, the rich became poorer, and they may not return to their old levels of wealth anytime soon.
articles.abstract: Over the last two years, the rich became poorer, and they may not return to their old levels of wealth anytime soon.
articles.lead_paragraph: The rich have been getting richer for so long that the trend has come to seem almost permanent.
articles.byline: By David Leonhardt and Geraldine Fabrikant

articles.headline: F.D.I.C. Seeks to Attract More Buyers of Banks
articles.snippet: The agency wants to attract more buyers for troubled institutions and is said to be considering a proposal to make it easier for private equity firms to buy them.
articles.abstract: The agency wants to attract more buyers for troubled institutions and is said to be considering a proposal to make it easier for private equity firms to buy them.
articles.lead_paragraph: Faced with a growing wave of bank failures, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation is taking extraordinary steps to attract buyers for troubled institutions to keep the fund that makes depositors whole from being drained.

articles.headline: C.I.A. Said to Use Outsiders to Put Bombs on Drones
articles.snippet: Contractors are involved in assembling and loading missiles used to attack Al Qaeda members, officials say.
articles.abstract: Contractors are involved in assembling and loading missiles used to attack Al Qaeda members, officials say.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  From a secret division at its North Carolina headquarters, the company formerly known as Blackwater has assumed a role in Washington’s most important counterterrorism program: the use of remotely piloted drones to kill Al Qaeda’s leaders, according to government officials and current and former employees.
articles.byline: By James Risen and Mark Mazzetti

articles.headline: Home Sales Lift Markets to Highest Close of ’09
articles.snippet: Shares jumped after a report showed existing home sales rose more than expected in July.
articles.abstract: Shares jumped after a report showed existing home sales rose more than expected in July.
articles.lead_paragraph: Wall Street’s pessimists and cautious investors keep waiting for the summertime rally to lose its footing. But on Friday, the bulls were again calling the shots.

articles.headline: World Bankers Suggest Rebound May Have Begun
articles.snippet: Central bankers from around the world are starting to focus on how to unwind the policies they used to fight the global financial crisis.
articles.abstract: Central bankers from around the world are starting to focus on how to unwind the policies they used to fight the global financial crisis.
articles.lead_paragraph: JACKSON HOLE, Wyo.  Central bankers from around the world expressed growing confidence on Friday that the worst of the financial crisis was over and that a global economic recovery was beginning to take shape.
